title: Thursday, 12th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hi! Hello. Welcome. Markets Live. FT Alphaville. Stocks, typing, ect.

BE11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-a09c-641a52eb180c

BE11:04am

The official exchange rate says $5,000 for one bitcoin.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Meanwhile, the unofficial darkweb exchange rate is $600 for 0.123 of a bitcoin.

BE11:04am

BE11:04am

At some point, perhaps quite soon, we'll hit a singularity where the number of real dollars you can swap for a bitcoin will equal the number of fake dollars.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

However, I've chosen to abstain from having any public view whatsoever on Bitcoin so perhaps best park that theme.

undefined
BE11:07am

It's a Thursday. There's quite a bit of corporate around, not much of interest.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Carillion mentioned already.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 47.25, up 3.75 (+8.62%), High: 47.25, Low: 42.75, Volume: 2.51m
BE11:08am

There's a report around that Serco's among the bidders for Carillion Healthcare.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Bloomberg, in fact, citing "people with knowledge of the matter."

BE11:09am

Serco "among several groups to hold talks"

BE11:09am

This isn't really surprising, no? These are the hospital maintenance contracts Carillion put up for sale as part of its £300m disposal pool?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

You'll also remember the reports earlier in the week that bondholders are tooling up ....

BE11:11am

Bringing in Houlihan Lokey, Strauss Hauer & Feld and Willkie Farr & Gallagher to fight their corner in the event of a debt-for-equity swap ....

BE11:12am

So, has Carillion been sounding out bondholders about that possibility?

11:12 am
BE11:12am

I phrase that as a question. Though I'm not sure I have to.

BE11:13am

Quick line from Jefferies.

BE11:14am

Conclusion: Bloomberg speculation linking Serco with Carillion's healthcare feels early
stage and would require strong value creation credentials to keep shareholders happy.
Detail: Serco has been linked to Carillion's healthcare business which was disclosed as up
for sale at their recent interim results and carries out hard and soft FM for NHS hospitals. Key
points: 1) The story feels early stage rather than a precursor to an imminent announcement;
2) Although Carillion's expected consideration for UK Healthcare and Canada is

£300m,

we expect that Canada is the majority of that suggesting consideration for UK healthcare is
likely to be low; 3) Serco is not FCF positive and still pays no dividend, consequently value
creation credentials would need to be compelling, and; 4) Although the cabinet office is
likely to be involved with contingency planning for Carillinon's UK contracts we sConclusion: Bloomberg speculation linking Serco with Carillion's healthcare feels early
stage and would require strong value creation credentials to keep shareholders happy.
Detail: Serco has been linked to Carillion's healthcare business which was disclosed as up
for sale at their recent interim results and carries out hard and soft FM for NHS hospitals. Key
points: 1) The story feels early stage rather than a precursor to an imminent announcement;
2) Although Carillion's expected consideration for UK Healthcare and Canada is greater than £300m,
we expect that Canada is the majority of that suggesting consideration for UK healthcare is
likely to be low; 3) Serco is not FCF positive and still pays no dividend, consequently value
creation credentials would need to be compelling, and; 4) Although the cabinet office is
likely to be involved with contingency planning for Carillinon's UK contracts we suspect this
primarily will relate to defence and HS2 as opposed to FM contracts with local hospitalsuspect this
primarily will relate to defence and HS2 as opposed to FM contracts with local hospitals

11:14 am
Serco Group PLC (SRP:LSE): Last: 118.40, down 0.1 (-0.08%), High: 118.70, Low: 117.70, Volume: 130.81k
BE11:15am

..... and a quick bit of JP Morgan from last week to emphasise that, whatever happens to Carillion, it's likely to be the shareholders who wear a lot of the cost.

BE11:16am

While we
appreciate management’s pragmatic approach, we believe guidance leaves
medium-term net debt around £5-600m higher than management’s target
level. It is unclear how this can be bridged, and we note that while disposals
are likely to help reduce leverage, they are also highly dilutive to any
remaining equity value.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Carillion is targeting 1.0 – 1.5x ND/EBITDA by
the end of 2018. We believe the group plans to sell or exit all non-UK
businesses, shrink UK construction, sell UK healthcare and sell all
remaining PPP assets. In addition, management has highlighted a £75m cost
saving program, announced the normalisation (to 90 days from 120) of its
reverse factoring facility and also identified a further £200m provision
required in support services.
 Medium-term outlook. On our forecasts, the above highlighted actions
produce FY19e net debt of c.£764m, compared to the group’s target of
c.£150-275m. How the remaining £5-600m gap is bridged is unclear.
 Conclusion. Unfortunately, while we understand management’s attempt to
reduce leverage via disposals, we note that this will have a negative impact
on our equity value. Disposal multiples are likely to be considerably lower
than those in our SoTP. Given this, we struggle to see sufficient “self-help”
measures available to the group. Further, we believe a c.11% FCF yield on a
post rights-issue basis is unlikely to be generous enough to attract significant
interest, given the risks involved.

BE11:16am

Still ..... maybe that Middle East bid will be arriving soon.

BE11:17am

A totally not made up story, that one. Completely not fictional.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Censored

undefined
BE11:17am

Just Eat mentioned on the right.

11:17 am
Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 739.50, up 36.5 (+5.19%), High: 758.50, Low: 718.00, Volume: 1.72m
BE11:18am

CMA's disagreed with the central pillar of the Just Eat investment case ....

BE11:18am

..... and decided it does compete with Deliveroo and the other gig economy takeaway thingmies.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

So, using the widest possible definition of the marketplace, The CMA's concluded that buying out what looks to be its only scale competitor won't lessen competition.

BE11:21am

Which means Just Eat and Rocket can continue their not terribly covert gambit of being number one and two in all possible markets, then selling out where they're number two and buying where they're number one.

BE11:21am

Totally not uncompetitive behaviour. Apparently.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Here's Goldman.

BE11:22am

n That Hungryhouse currently provides limited competition to JE (too small, too
few unique restaurants) and that actually Deliveroo, UberEATS and Amazon
Restaurants generally present a greater competitive challenge to JE than
Hungryhouse.
n The CMA took into account consumers’ options to order directly from
restaurants, either via telephone, online or in person. This is important because it
places online takeaway aggregators in competition with telephone and in-person
ordering, making the competitive sphere much larger than solely the online
space.
n These conclusions are provisional, the CMA is asking for views on the findings
and will reassess before making a final decision. The final report is due mid/late
November and the statutory deadline is November 30, 201 7 (per CMA timetable)

BE11:22am

While we take no view on the pending final decision from the CMA, we believe the
provisional findings noted above could be read positively for a sector where
consolidation has already been a key strategy for the largest players, and could
possibly be in the future.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

And Canaccord.

BE11:23am

In 2016, Hungryhouse had c£28m of revenues and made a loss of c£12m. We would
expect Just Eat to make a profit of c£14m on the same revenues.

BE11:23am

JE's share price is up 23% YTD despite a lacklustre Q1. Investors appear to be rewarding
companies that come to dominate their sector and punishing those that struggle to
match their scale.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Citi.

BE11:24am

EPS Accretive for Just Eat – We incorporate Hungryhouse within our FY18e
forecasts for Just Eat. As shown in Figure 1, we estimate the deal to be 10% EPS
accretive. Our estimate is based on Hungryhouse being on track to achieve £35
million revenue in FY17e, which infers c.20% YoY growth. We assume Just Eat will
have 25% revenue attrition once the platform is consolidated and a 75%
incremental margin. This is above Just Eat’s £12-15 million cost synergies estimate.
 Implications – The provisional CMA clearance has positive read across for both
Just Eat and Delivery Hero. We have Buy ratings on both companies given our
expectations for strong earnings growth as both companies consolidate leadership
in key markets and benefit from the continued growth in online food delivery.

BE11:24am

And Cazenove.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

 We continue to see valuation as attractive. On JPMe, JUST EAT shares trade on 27.2x/18.8x 17E/18E
EV/EBITDA with a 2-yr PEG of 0.8. Given that cash conversion of EBIT is roughly 100%, if we apply an
Equity FCF yield of 4% on the UK business and add the €450m we value the Brazil operations, the
International operations are free - therefore providing plenty of room for further upside.
 Current short-term risk appears on margins. We await an update from CEO Peter Plumb in the next
months on the company’s investment approach (i.e. investment in delivery services) going forward.

BE11:26am

And Investec.

BE11:26am

Our pre-deal indicative modelling suggests the hungryhouse acquisition could be 7% accretive to EBITDA in FY18E. This suggests EBITDA forecasts rising from £211m to £226m (+39% growth YoY vs. +30% on our existing numbers and FY17E +41%), and implying an EBITDA contribution from hungryhouse of £15m.
Stronger market position/positive economics: the addition of hungryhouse should also help strengthen Just Eat’s market position, giving it greater scale in its largest and most profitable territory and driving marketing efficiencies over time. We currently forecast 54% EBITDA margins in the UK in FY18E, but see material upside, with peers in leading positions in smaller markets generating margins in excess of 60%.
Attractive valuation: Just Eat offers sector-leading earnings growth within mid/large cap UK internet stocks. The shares trade on c.21x CY18E EV/EBITDA and c.33x P/E on our current forecasts (i.e. pre-consolidation of hungryhouse).
Next news flow: Just Eat reports Q3 trading on 31 October. We expect momentum to have continued, with easier comps relative to H1, and partial benefit from the X Factor sponsorship likely supportive. Buy

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Our base case on JE is, of course, that 33x is a lot to pay for a weak defacto monopoly that can only really be protected by advertising and whose growth seems to be capped around urbanisation

BE11:29am

.... and whose earnings growth towards the outer years depends largely on fee creep in a market where cost inflation is already becoming problematic and a lot of operators are borderline profitable.

BE11:30am

But perhaps we're wrong and the entire army of sellside is right. Dunno. Take your pick.

11:29 am
undefined
BE11:31am

............... so ....................... what's next?

BE11:33am

N Brown? Sure.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

H1 beats, guidance up, shares down.

BE11:04am

So ............ Bitcoin's at a record high!

BE11:35am

Shore's house, so they can explain the main points ....

11:35 am
BE11:36am

N Brown’s H1 2018 results demonstrate the growing impact of its ‘digital first’ model, with encouraging Product sales growth and good momentum across key performance indicators. Underlying PTP of £32.2m is reported comfortably ahead of consensus (£29.5m) and higher than our expectations (£31.0m). EPS is 8.77p, a little lower yoy and the interim dividend is maintained at 5.67p. Current trading is ‘on-track’ and we reiterate our FY2018 CPTP forecast of £81.2m, and expect consensus CPTP to edge up from £77.7m. With the heavy lifting of transformational change considerably undertaken management is now in a position to talk about future growth levers – UK apparel share gains, international markets & partnerships – enabling this hybrid company to press forward on the front foot. Let us not forget, versus admittedly faster growing pure-play online companies, that N Brown has 72% web participation, is profitable (greater than 9% EBIT margin) and provides a healthy income stream. Compare & contrast. HOUSE STOCK.

BE11:37am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:38am

.............. eventually, when it chooses to open.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

N Brown’s H1 profits came in c£3m ahead of PHe and consensus.
Product sales and trading KPIs all show good traction, although
the impact of fx on input prices has hit margins as expected. Given
the first-half beat and the closure of loss making stores, we
upgrade our full-year PBT forecast by £4m to £77.6m. With
autumn/winter likely to have started well, we expect management
to be in confident form today. N Brown is now on a more even
keel, it’s time to prove that the business can deliver a return to
sustainable earnings growth; trading on c16x PER, the shares have
already taken on board recent improvements. Hold.

BE11:39am

It’s been a fairly torrid time for N Brown,
with profits down c20% since launching the initial revitalisation programme.
While the level of investment and change required was greater than expected, it’s
now time to show that the benefits can be delivered. We expect a/w to have
started well, in keeping with wider apparel markets. On 16x PER, the shares
have already reflected stronger trading in our view.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

(@FJP: you're ahead of me. I've not read the statement.)

BE11:41am

Hey, ROTR, can I crowdsource something?

BE11:41am

Someone's just forwarded me this: https://profitmaximiser.co.uk/

11:41 am
BE11:42am

It sets off all sorts of red flags, even in the rather questionable world of turf accountant tipstering.

BE11:43am

But I don't want to jump to conclusions. If you, dear ROTR, can jump to conclusions (and keep them on the right side of libel laws) that'd be most convenient, thanks.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Okay, back to proper stuff.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 928.50, up 15 (+1.64%), High: 938.00, Low: 913.00, Volume: 866.74k
BE11:44am

Numbers are decent!

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Though it might just be me, but is it getting increasingly difficult just to see how many people are buying Sky telly?

BE11:46am

There's an awful lot of Q and OTT and NowTV and broadband and mobile going into the numbers

BE11:47am

As you'd expect on a structurally obsolete core product, I guess.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

here's Citi to summarise where we are.

BE11:47am

To the extent that results are a focus, the 1Q trading at Sky is
encouraging both in terms of revenue growth and EBITDA. The relevance of this is
not to the potential upside which is still going to be somewhat pegged to the offer
price of 1075p but rather to the perceived downside if a deal should fall apart. The
market seems to think Sky would revert to 750p on a deal break – i.e. roughly the
price it was before the bid – this set of results would suggest this is too bearish.
With this in mind, even in the context of the bid, we think the 1Q will be taken well.

BE11:48am

1Q Trends — Sky only releases limited financials/KPIs at the 1Q/3Q mark but the
trends appear encouraging. In terms of overall financials the group reported 1Q
revenue growth of 5% and a 1Q EBITDA uplift of 11% (rising to 15% if one excludes
‘investment in new business’). By country revenue/EBITDA was up 4%/11% in the
UK/Ireland; 8%/35% in Germany/Austria; and 2%/8% in Italy. In terms of KPIs the
headline customer additions were +160k (o/w 90k were in Germany and 70k in UK)
and the company also gave some throwaway lines on mobile (108k adds in the
quarter), pay as you go sales (+12%) and customer viewing of Sky channels (up
10% across the business). Looking at this vs. Citi/consensus, the trend is perhaps a
bit behind the FY runrate that we expect both for revenue (5% in the UK/Ireland, 3%
in Italy and 11% in Germany/Austria) and EBITDA (c. +14%), that said it appears to
be comfortably ahead of consensus.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Focus #1: Focus on Total Revenue Growth — The bear case on Sky always was
that financial momentum would stall once overall sub growth starts to slow. The
counterargument to this was that increased product sell through (mobile,
broadband, fibre), transactional revenues (pay as you go and entertainment sales)
and segmentation (Now TV/Sky Ticket at the low end; SkyQ at the high end) would
allow the group to continue to post solid revenue growth. It looks like the latter is
coming through with decent momentum across the business.

BE11:48am

Focus #2: Germany/Austria and Italy Only Just Beginning to Deliver — Since
the bid there has been limited focus on operational trends in general. This is
particularly acute for the German/Italian operations. This set of results, however,
gives a sense of the potential: in Germany sub growth and viewing continues to be
strong and this is before the roll out of Sky Q (expected in the 3Q) and the first
impact of Sky Originals (Babylon Berlin to air in October). In Italy there is a move to
stability in the sub base and this is before considering the market repair (as
evidenced by the Champions League rights win) which will kick in from next year

BE11:48am

Implications — The 1Q EBITDA was £582m and while there are some timing
impacts (only 2 months of BL inflation ) and there are investments yet to kick in, a
historic rule of thumb has been that the FY should pro-rata be in line with the
quarterly run rate of profitability. On this basis, FY EBITDA could come in at £2.3bn+
vs. current consensus of c. £2.2bn. This would imply a c. 3% consensus upgrade.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

(@Lemmy: suggest trying Mobdro, for research purposes.)

BE11:50am

And Liberum.

BE11:50am

We upgrade Sky to Buy, with the same target price of 1060p. Q1 results look broadly healthy and the shares have fallen back to a level which we think do not reflect the likelihood of the Fox bid for Sky being cleared by the regulators, thus we think Sky offers a short-term investment opportunity.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Sky has delivered what looks like a strong operational performance with new customer growth of 70K in the UK, double what they did last year Q1 and 160K in total although Italy was flat and there were no comments on churn. On revenues, like for like up 5% to £3,296m, with a new line item Established Businesses EBITDA - excluding the investment in Sky Mobile and their OTT service in Spain – was up 15% underlying yoy to £606m, with actual adjusted EBITDA up 11% to £582m and operational costs flat demonstrating tight cost control. Although Sky pointed to uncertainty in the broader consumer environment, the company stated it was on track with its plans.

BE11:51am

Sky’s share price has fallen back to 913.5p, a significant discount to the 1075p Fox bid, with Sky shareholders also receiving a 10p special dividend paid in February 2018, on concerns whether the bid is cleared by the Government and / or that the political environment in the UK has turned more hostile with the rising popularity of the Labour party, led by Jeremy Corbyn, which is hostile to Fox. We think the concerns are overdone and believe the deal will pass. We would make the following comments.

The Competition and Markets Authority has to come back to the Secretary of State (SoS) for DCMS by March 6th 2018 following her referral. The SoS then will make her decision. In effect, it is likely that the deal will be completed by the end of H1'18 which would mean a Labour Government would have to be incoming before that date to pose a threat. We do not think this is likely.
While the deal is being referred on the grounds of Media Plurality and Broadcasting Standards, we do not think either issue is likely to be a major problem for Fox’s bid and regulator Ofcom has again defended its views on its decision on Fox, which suggests there has not been a change in how the bid is being perceived.

undefined
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Oh, should've mentioned that it looks like James will be re-elected at the Sky AGM today.

BE11:55am

Anyway, nearly there. What are we missing?

BE11:56am

JPM crossed the tape earlier, looks like a beat.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

*JPMORGAN 3Q FICC SALES & TRADING REV $3.16B, EST. $3.18B

BE11:57am

And GVC, as noted ......

GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 889.50, up 22 (+2.54%), High: 893.50, Low: 865.00, Volume: 4.39m
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Interesting backgrounder from Murad earlier in the month, by the way: https://www.ft.com...-b797-b61809486fe2

BE11:58am

[Ladbrokes and GVC] are further towards completing a deal than previously known, having agreed on the shape of a new executive team and board, according to several people close to both groups.

BE12:00pm

Not wishing to repeat myself, but neither company is in a takeover period and we last hit that story hard in late August.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

As in .....

BE12:01pm

Online gambling group GVC approached Ladbrokes Coral, the UK bookmaker with 3,500 high street shops, in recent weeks with a takeover offer worth as much as £3.6bn to create one of the world’s largest gambling companies. According to two people close to the discussions, the talks have since broken down and are no longer active.

BE12:01pm

So ...... are talks active or not? Hello, Takeover Panel?

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Anyway, back to today.

BE12:03pm

Here's Berenberg.

BE12:03pm

● Excellent set of Q3 KPIs just released: On a reported basis, group daily net gaming revenue
(NGR) was up by 10% versus Q3 2016 at EUR243m, and up by 13% in constant currency (cc).
Underlying NGR (ie stripping out Euro 2016 and Kalixa, which was disposed of in May 2017)
increased 18% on a reported basis and 21% in cc.
● Sports brands recorded a 14% yoy increase in daily NGR on an underlying basis. The gross
win margin for the period was 11.2% (10.5% Q3 2016), which is ahead of the company’s
guided long-term sustainable average of c10%. Daily wagers were 4% ahead in cc, adjusting
for Euro 2016, and underlying wager growth in cc was 8%, prompted by the new bwin
marketing campaign launched in August.
● Daily NGR for games brands increased by 15% (17% in cc) over the same period last year. NGR
for partypoker grew by 48% yoy, thanks to product improvement and increased marketing
investment. NGR for casino brands also grew in Q3, while bingo returned to underlying
growth during the period.
● On current consensus estimates, which we do not think will move today, single-digit growth
is expected for Q4 (we forecast +7% yoy on a reported basis), which seems conservative at
this stage (the company has stated that Q4 started strong).
● We expect the stock to be strongly up today. Also, we flag that top-line growth in Q4 and
2018-19 is likely to be higher than what currently consensus is factoring in. We keep GVC as
our top pick in gaming, thanks to underlying growth opportunities and potential for valueaccretive M&A.
● We value the stock with a DCF method (10% WACC, 2% perpetual growth).

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

@Helen78: that's a very good question.

BE12:04pm

A reminder that Turkey is GVC's second-biggest market by sales.

BE12:05pm

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

And 32% of revenues are from markets not regulated or in the process of being regulated, to use GVC's definition.

undefined
BE12:07pm

Cripes, look at the time.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Let's wrap up. I've a day job to be getting on with.

BE12:08pm

Thanks for your time and patience. Back tomorrow.

BE12:09pm

Afternoon all.

11:34 am
N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 337.70, down 12.3 (-3.51%), High: 355.00, Low: 334.70, Volume: 577.21k
